data.title: Shaun Livingston's success a feel-good story

data.text:
Shaun Livingston played 18 games with the Thunder. Eight at the end of the Thunder's inaugural season, 10 at the start of the next season.

When the Thunder traded for Eric Maynor in December 2009, Livingston was waived. It was nothing personal. Everyone -- literally, everyone -- was pulling for Livingston. One of the worst injuries in NBA history made Livingston a sympathetic figure.

On Feb. 26, 2007, Livingston drove in for a layup against the Charlotte Bobcats and landed as awkwardly as a player can land. His leg went one way, his knee another. Livingston suffered one of the most catastrophic knee injuries in sports history, derailing a promising career.

But Livingston has gone from derailed to rerailed. Tuesday night in Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals, Livingston scored 18 points, including 14 in the second quarter, as the Warriors beat the Rockets 110-106. It was a career playoff high for Livingston, who played in 12 postseason games for the Clippers in 2006 but never saw the playoffs again until last year with Brooklyn.

Livingston has lived quite the nomadic life since that injury against the Bobcats. Livingston, a 6-foot-7 point guard, was the fourth overall pick in the 2004 NBA Draft, out of Peoria (Ill.) Central High School. That's right. Livingston has been around so long, he was drafted out of high school. 2004 was a long time ago. Also selected in that draft were Dwight Howard, Emeka Okafor, Ben Gordon, Devin Harris, Luol Deng, Andre Iguodala, Robert Swift, Sebastian Telfair, Al Jefferson, Kirk Snyder, Josh Smith, J.R. Smith, Delonte West and Tony Allen. Second-round picks included Andre Emmett and Royal Ivey.

Livingston was part of a young Clipper core that was quite promising. Elton Brand, Sam Cassell, Chris Kaman and Corey Maggette. The long-beleaguered Clippers made the '06 playoffs and even won a series.

But Livingston suffered the knee injury, the Clippers staggered to a 40-42 record, the Clips went back to rebuilding and Livingston began trying to resurrect his career.

Livingston missed the entire 2007-08 and began quite the odyssey.

Since that injury, Livingston has been released five times, traded three times and not re-signed three times.

He's played for nine teams, plus the Wizards twice, and not counting Memphis and Houston, which traded for him and released him.

Here is Livingston's journey:

July 2008: Released by the Clippers

October 2008: Signed by the Heat

January 2009: Traded to the Grizzlies (for a top-55 protected second-round draft pick)

January 2009: Released by the Grizzlies

March 2009: Signed by the Thunder

December 2009: Released by the Thunder

February 2010: Signed by the Wizards

July 2010: Signed by the Hornets

June 2011: Traded to the Bucks

June 2012: Traded to the Rockets

October 2012: Released by the Rockets (to make roster space for the James Harden trade)

November 2012: Signed by the Wizards

December 2012: Released by the Wizards

December 2012: Signed by the Cavaliers

July 2013: Signed by the Nets

July 2014: Signed by the Warriors.

Even in the vagabond NBA, that's quite the tour. Livingston has made 11 roster changes since the Clippers, and this season with the Warriors is the most games, 78, he's played in any of those stops.

That's what happens when an athletic point guard no longer is athletic.

When Livingston was a Thunder, he was Russell Westbrook's backup. He averaged 17.8 minutes and 4.0 points per game. Seemed perfectly fine.

But after Livingston was released and Maynor arrived, we saw something completely different. Maynor came in and made all kinds of plays as a traditional point guard, and we suddenly realized why Livingston no longer was on the roster.

But he didn't quit. He kept working. Kept trying. And the last two seasons, Livingston has been rewarded. He was a valuable Net, making 54 starts for Brooklyn, including 10 in the playoffs.

And this season, Livingston is the backup point guard on the wildly entertaining Warriors.

Livingston isn't your typical Warrior. He's taken two 3-pointers all season. Missed them both. Livingston is a driver, but not with the explosiveness you need to dominate. And he's a passer. Livingston is third on the team in assists, and per 36 minutes, he's second, behind only Steph Curry.

Livingston, who turns 30 in September, has turned himself into a valuable, functional ballplayer on a really good team. What more could he ask for, especially after the events of Feb. 26, 2007?
